advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> DUTCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Richard de Keijzer</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Success in the future will depend upon confidence in using new technologies. That's why a computer in the home has to be more than just an interesting diversion or even a useful tool. It has to an investment in tomorrow for you and your children... </font> <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Alice, a computer for all levels"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST VICTOR ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>with the original Victor design.<br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The Victor 9000. It's a desktop system computer designed to be a "cut above" the rest...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FROM WALKMAN TO M5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This US dealer advert says that the designer of the M5, Toshiaki Kamijo was before the Walkman inventor in Sony CIE.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>New version with Shugart 360 KB formatted capacity floppy drives. Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">North Star has quadrupled the disk capacity of the Horizon computer but prices have increased a modest 15 percent. On a dollar per byte basis, that's a bargain that is hard to beat!...</font><br><br> 1979 prices for assembled versions including 32KB RAM, one parallel and two serial I/O ports:<br> 1 F.D. version: <b>$2565</b><br> 2 F.D. version: <b>$3215</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Doctors, it gonna cure your work" <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 4</strong></font><br><blockquote>These are fake screenshots, that is to say drawn by an artist.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #20</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to datareign.co.uk for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>...released in "l'Ordinateur Individuel" magazine n°12<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Fabien Neck and its <a href="http://www.system-cfg.com/" target="_blank">website</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QD VERSION ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>1980 Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Our new QD model has all of the features of our phenomenally popular SuperBrain with the addition of double-sided disk drives and an extra of dynamic RAM. So, for only a modest increase in price, you can order your next SuperBrain with more than twice the disk and memory storage capability. But, best of all, the new QD model has the same tough, rugged construction and exceptional quality that made our SuperBrain such a success. </font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"> Our Peripheral Expansion System gives you plug-in cards for memory expansion, P-Code capabilities, a disk drive controler and the RS-232 interface. You can also add a modem, speech synthetiser, disk drive and matrix printer...<br><br> ... TI BASIC is built into the computer, but it can also handle TI Extended BASIC, UCSD Pascal, TI LOGO, TMS-9900 Assembly language and TI PILOT ... </font></blockquote>

computer.description:
Very little is known about this system. Help largely welcomed !
It is of course a business oriented computer. It looks like it is an all-in-one system with the keyboard, the display and the motherboard built-in the same plastic case. Or maybe the keyboard is separated, it is not clear looking at the only picture we have so far. The double external 5.25'' disk-drive seems huge...
An 8" disk unit (1 MB) and hard disk (5, 10 or 20 MB) were also available for this system.
computer.keyboard: Full stroke keyboard with numeric keypad
computer.name: DY 80
